abstract.title: Introduction
abstract.para: This guide contains configuration information for system administrators working with &GRAM;. It describes procedures typically performed by system administrators, including &GRAM; software installation, configuration, testing, and debugging. Readers should be familiar with the &GRAM; Key Concepts to understand the motivation for and interaction between the various deployed components.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The Globus Toolkit provides &GRAM;: a service to submit, monitor, and cancel jobs on Grid computing resources. In &GRAM;, a job consists of a computation and, optionally, file transfer and management operations related to the computation. Some users, particularly interactive ones, benefit from accessing output data files as the job is running. Monitoring consists of querying for and/or subscribing to status information, such as job state changes.

&GRAM; relies on mechanisms for security, and interacts with GridFTP services to stage files to compute resources. Please see their respective Administrator's guides for information about installing, configuring, and managing those systems. In particular, you must understand the tasks in and install the basic &GRAM; packages, and complete the tasks in .

section.title: Planning your &GRAM; installation
section.para: Before installing &GRAM; on a server, you'll first need to plan what Local Resource Managers (LRMs) you want &GRAM; to interface with, what LRM you want to have as your default &GRAM; service, and whether you'll be using the &seg; to process LRM events.

&GRAM; requires a few services to be running to function: the Gatekeeper and the Scheduler Event Generator (SEG). The supported way to run these services is via the System-V style init scripts provided with the &GRAM;-related packages. The gatekeeper daemon can also be configured to start via an internet superserver such as inetd or xinetd though that is beyond the scope of this document. The &seg; can not be run in that way.

section.title: Choosing an LRM Adapter
section.para: &GRAM; in GT version supports the following LRM adapters: Condor, PBS, GridEngine, and Fork. These LRM adapters translate &GRAM; job specifications into LRM-specific job descriptions and scripts to run them, as well as interfaces to the LRM to determine job termination status.

If you're not familiar with the supported LRMs, you might want to start with the Fork one to get familiar with how &GRAM; works. This adapter simply forks the job and runs it on the &GRAM; node. You can then install one of the other LRMs and its adapter to provide batch or high-throughput job scheduling.

section.title: Default &GRAM; Service
section.para: &GRAM; can be configured to support multiple LRMs on the same service machine. In that case, one LRM is typically configured as the default LRM which is used when a client uses a shortened version of a &GRAM; resource name. A common configuration is to configure a batch system interface as the default, and provide the jobmanager-fork service as well for simple jobs, such as creating directories or staging data.

section.title: Job Status Method
section.para: &GRAM; has two ways of determining job state transitions: polling the LRM and using the Scheduler Event Generator (SEG) service. When polling, each user's globus-job-manager will periodically execute an LRM-specific command to determine the state of each job. On systems with many users, or with users submitting a large number of jobs, this can cause significant resource use on the &GRAM; service machine. Instead, the &GRAM; service can be configured (on a per-LRM basis) to use the &seg; service to more efficiently process LRM state changes. Not all LRM adapters provide an interface to the &seg;, and some require LRM-specific configuration to work properly. This is described in more detail.

section.title: Installing LRM Adapter Packages
section.para: There are several LRM adapters included in the GT version. For some, there is a -setup-poll and -setup-seg package which installs the adapter and configuration file needed for job status via polling or the &seg; program.
There are three ways to get LRM adapters: as RPM packages, as Debian packages, and from the source installer. These installation methods are described in .

chapter.title: Common Administrative Tasks
chapter.para: There are several tools provided with GT version to manage &GRAM;, as well as OS-specific tools to start and stop some of the services. There are tools to manage user authorization, which services are enabled, which scheduler event generator modules are enabled, and to test the globus-gatekeeper service.

section.title: Managing &GRAM; Users
section.para: Before a user may interact with the &GRAM; service to submit jobs, he or she must be authorized to use the service. In order to be authorized, a &GRAM; administrator must add the user's credential name and local account mapping to the /etc/grid-mapfile. This can be done using the and tools. For more information, see the manual.

section.title: Starting and Stopping &GRAM; services
section.para: In order to run the service, the globus-gatekeeper, and, if applicable to your configuration, the &seg; services must be running on your system. The packages for these services include init scripts and configuration files which can be used to configure, start, and stop the service.

The &gatekeeper; and &seg; init scripts handle the following actions: start, stop, status, restart, condrestart, try-restart, reload, and force-reload. The &seg; script also accepts another optional parameter to start or stop a particular &seg; module. If the second parameter is not present, then all services will be acted on.

section.title: Debian Specifics
section.para: If you installed using Debian packaging tools, then the services will automatically be started upon installation. To start or stop the service, use the command invoke-rc.d with the service name and action.

section.title: RPM Specifics
section.para: If you installed using the RPM packaging tools, then the services will be installed but not enabled by default. To enable the services to start at boot time, use the commands: &rootprompt;chkconfig globus-gatekeeper on &rootprompt;chkconfig globus-scheduler-event-generator on
To start or stop the services, use the service command to run the init scripts with the service name and action and optional &seg; module.

section.title: Enabling and Disabling &GRAM; Services
section.para: The &GRAM; packages described in will automatically register themselves with the &gatekeeper; and &seg; services. The first LRM adapter installed will be configured as the default Job Manager service. To list the installed services, change the default, or disable a service, use the tool.

example.title: Using globus-gatekeeper-admin to set the default service
example.para: This example shows how to use the globus-gatekeeper-admin tool to list the available services and then choose one as the default:
example.screen: &rootprompt;globus-gatekeeper-admin -l jobmanager-condor [ENABLED] jobmanager-fork-poll [ENABLED] jobmanager-fork [ALIAS to jobmanager-fork-poll] &rootprompt;globus-gatekeeper-admin -e jobmanager-condor -n jobmanager &rootprompt;globus-gatekeeper-admin -l jobmanager-condor [ENABLED] jobmanager-fork-poll [ENABLED] jobmanager [ALIAS to jobmanager-condor] jobmanager-fork [ALIAS to jobmanager-fork-poll]

section.title: Enabling and Disabling SEG Modules
section.para:
The -setup-seg packages described in will automatically register themselves with the &seg; service. To disable a module from running when the &seg; service is started, use the tool. Using globus-scheduler-event-generator-admin to disable a SEG module
This example shows how to stop the pbs globus-scheduler-event-generator module and disable it so it will not restart when the system is rebooted:
&rootprompt;/etc/init.d/globus-scheduler-event-generator stop pbs Stopped globus-scheduler-event-generator [ OK ] &rootprompt;globus-scheduler-event-generator-admin -d pbs &rootprompt;globus-scheduler-event-generator-admin -l pbs [DISABLED]
